title: The Phantom Proposal Heist
setting: Avalanche Governance Council Chambers, Digital Realm
incidentDescription: At 3:17 AM, a malicious governance proposal passed with 67% of the vote, granting emergency withdrawal rights to a mysterious address. Within minutes, 2.5 million AVAX vanished from the protocol treasury. The proposal appeared legitimate but contained hidden code that activated after approval.

victim.name: TreasureDAO Protocol
victim.whatHappened: Treasury completely drained through governance exploit
victim.technicalDetails: Proposal #247 contained obfuscated code that granted withdrawer role to address 0x789...

suspects.name: Elena Vasquez
suspects.avaxRole: Core contributor to multiple Avalanche protocols
suspects.motive: Recently fired from TreasureDAO for proposing risky investment strategies
suspects.alibi: Claims she was working on a new protocol launch all night
suspects.technicalCapability: Expert smart contract developer, knows governance systems inside-out

suspects.name: Marcus Thompson
suspects.motive: Lost $500K in TreasureDAO's failed investment and wants compensation
suspects.alibi: Was attending an investor meeting in Singapore (timestamped video calls)
suspects.technicalCapability: Business background, limited technical skills, hires developers

suspects.name: Dr. Sarah Chen
suspects.avaxRole: Audits smart contracts for Avalanche protocols
suspects.motive: Discovered the vulnerability 6 months ago, TreasureDAO ignored her warnings
suspects.alibi: Home alone writing a research paper on governance attacks
suspects.technicalCapability: PhD in Computer Science, expert in smart contract vulnerabilities

suspects.name: Alex Rivera
suspects.avaxRole: Runs 12 validator nodes, participates in governance
suspects.motive: Needs funds to expand validator operations and compete with larger players
suspects.alibi: Was monitoring validator nodes during network upgrade
suspects.technicalCapability: Strong understanding of Avalanche consensus, moderate smart contract skills

clues.description: The malicious proposal was submitted from IP address 192.168.0.115, which traces to a coffee shop in downtown Seattle. Security cameras show someone using a laptop with distinctive stickers at 2:45 AM.
clues.avaxConcept: Governance proposal submission and IP tracking

educationalLinks.briefExplanation: When someone manipulates voting to control a protocol
educationalLinks.detailedExplanation: A governance attack occurs when an attacker accumulates enough governance tokens to propose and pass malicious proposals. In DeFi protocols, governance tokens give holders voting rights on protocol changes. If someone gets >51% of tokens (or enough to reach quorum), they can vote to drain treasuries, change fee structures, or modify smart contracts for personal benefit.

clues.description: Blockchain analysis reveals the proposal was funded by a flash loan from Aave protocol. 50,000 AVAX was borrowed, used to buy governance tokens, vote, then repaid within the same transaction block.
clues.avaxConcept: Flash loans and governance token manipulation

educationalLinks.briefExplanation: Borrowing crypto that must be repaid in the same transaction
educationalLinks.detailedExplanation: Flash loans allow borrowing large amounts of cryptocurrency without collateral, but the loan must be repaid within the same blockchain transaction. If not repaid, the entire transaction fails. Attackers use flash loans to manipulate prices, exploit arbitrage, or temporarily gain voting power in governance attacks.

clues.description: The smart contract code in the proposal contains a deliberate obfuscation technique called 'constructor aliasing' - a rare method only taught in advanced security courses at 3 universities.

educationalLinks.briefExplanation: Bugs in code that attackers can exploit
educationalLinks.detailedExplanation: Smart contracts are immutable code, so bugs become permanent vulnerabilities. Common issues include reentrancy attacks (calling functions repeatedly), integer overflow (numbers becoming too large), and access control bugs (wrong permissions). Audits help find these issues before deployment.

clues.description: Coffee shop security footage shows someone wearing a 'BlockSec Research Conference 2024' hoodie - the same conference where Dr. Chen presented her governance attack research paper.

clues.avaxConcept: Blockchain address analysis and timestamp correlation

solution.method: Used flash loan to temporarily acquire governance tokens, submitted obfuscated proposal, voted it through, then executed the hidden withdrawal function
solution.motive: Revenge against TreasureDAO for ignoring her security warnings and frustration with DeFi protocols not taking security seriously
evidence: IP address traces to coffee shop where she was seen
Flash loan technique matches her research expertise
Obfuscation method from her academic background
Conference hoodie identifies her in footage
Withdrawal address created when she discovered the vulnerability
solution.howCluesPointToCulprit: Clue 1 eliminates Marcus (wrong location), Clue 2 eliminates Alex (lacks flash loan skills), Clues 3-5 all point to Dr. Chen through her academic background, research expertise, and the timing correlation between her vulnerability discovery and the attack preparation.

educationalGoals: Understand how governance attacks work in DeFi protocols
Learn about flash loans and their risks
Understand the importance of security audits
Learn how blockchain forensics can trace attackers
